name: Preserved Fish
description: Fish preserved through salting, smoking, or drying for extended storage and transport. A staple protein source for Venetians and an important trade good.

historicalNotes.historicalSignificance: Preserved fish was essential to Venice's food security and maritime activities. The city's position as a trading hub meant it could import salt cheaply, allowing for large-scale fish preservation. This preserved protein source enabled long sea voyages and provided year-round nutrition for the population, especially during religious fasting periods when meat was forbidden but fish was permitted.
historicalNotes.culturalContext: Preserved fish became deeply embedded in Venetian cuisine, with distinctive recipes developing to make the most of these preserved products. The smell of fish preservation was a common feature of certain neighborhoods, particularly around the Rialto contract.
